awd_titl_txt: EAR/IF:   Prototype Investigations into Integrated GPS/Seismic Networks for Improved Finite Fault Slip Modeling and Earthquake Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent great earthquakes and ensuing tsunamis in Sumatra, Chile and Japan have demonstrated the need for accurate ground displacements that fully characterize the great amplitudes and broad dynamic range associated with these vast, complex ruptures. Our ability to model these events, whether in real-time or after the fact, is limited by the weaknesses of both seismic and geodetic networks. Geodetic instruments provide the static component as well as coarse dynamic motions but are much less precise than seismic instruments, especially in the vertical direction. Seismic instruments, in turn, provide exceptionally-sensitive dynamic motions but typically have difficulty recovering unbiased near-field static offsets and low-frequency motions because of contamination, for example, from instrument tilt. This three-year project is demonstrating a new paradigm for studying the processes of large earthquakes and the hazards they pose.  Accurate three-dimensional seismogeodetic waveforms (broadband displacements and velocities) that span the full spectrum of seismic motion will be achieved through integration of geodetic and seismic measurements instrumentation developed at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. The main science objectives are to improve finite-fault slip inversions through the optimal combination of geodetic and seismic data at the observational level and to investigate appropriate methodologies to perform full waveform inversions using the resulting data. With UNAVCO engineers, a test bed of integrated GPS/seismic stations is being established at existing real-time Plate Boundary Observatory stations along the southern San Andreas fault system as a prototype for further expansion along the Western North America plate margin. The stations are being upgraded with low-cost MEMS accelerometers and a Geodetic Module that will synchronize the GPS and accelerometer data and estimate seismogeodetic displacements and velocities.

The project is installing and testing seismic upgrades to existing GPS monitoring stations for improved response to and modeling and understanding of large earthquakes and ensuing tsunamis, such as recent ones in Sumatra, Chile and Japan. The broader impacts of this project are significant in terms of scientific value, engineering infrastructure, civilian use, and economic impact, and are related for the most part to the real-time nature and capabilities of enhanced GPS/seismic monitoring. The new observations contribute directly to natural hazards research and early warning systems for earthquakes, volcanoes and tsunamis, to atmospheric research including short-term weather forecasting and related flooding hazards, and to earthquake engineering research for large structures (e.g., bridges, buildings, dams). The ultimate goal is to save lives and minimize damage to essential infrastructure. The new observations also contribute to civilian applications requiring precise real-time positioning (e.g., surveying, geographic information systems, agriculture) and hence to economic stimulus. Finally, the project supports collaborative and interdisciplinary research, education of technologically sophisticated graduate students, strengthening of diversity in support of workforce development, and enhancement of curricula at a variety of levels through engagement new types of data sets that have direct societal impact.

por.por_cntn:
Our project is focused on earthquake early warning and rapid response systems as a way of mitigating the effects of significant earthquakes on people and infrastructure. There are hundreds of Global Positioning System (GPS) monitoring stations on the West Coast that can be used to precisely determine how a station moves during an earthquake - it experiences both shaking and permanent motion that can be measured with GPS. Seismic instruments operated by seismologists only measure the non-permanent shaking that one feels during an earthquake. However, they are much more precise than GPS instruments, but have trouble during large earthquakes. We've developed an optimal way to combine both GPS and seismic data so that it enhances the strengths and overcomes the weaknesses of each system. We call this approach seismogeodesy. So we'd like to upgrade GPS stations with seismic instruments to improve our warning system. However, seismic instruments are expensive so we've built in our laboratory at Scripps Institution of Oceanography low-cost seismic instruments (accelerometers that are found in smart phones) that can be added to existing GPS stations. As part of our project, we have upgraded 25 GPS stations with these instruments, 15 in southern California and 10 in the San Francisco Bay Area, after successful laboratory testing. The stations have been deployed to “catch” large earthquakes in the areas of largest seismic risk in California. The data from each network are collected continuously in real time (with a latency of about 1 second) at a high rate (once per second for the GPS data and 100 times per second for the accelerometer data) and the positions of the stations are tracked in time with a latency of only a few seconds. Changes in position during an earthquakes precisely determine the shaking and permanent motions, which are used to issue an early warning and a very rapid estimate of earthquake magnitude. This allows the intensity of ground motion to be determined over the affected region.

The impact of our research is significant in terms of communication of critical information in times of emergency to first responders and to the public, as part of robust early warning systems. This can be significant in saving lives and minimizing injuries as a result of natural hazards through direct monitoring as part of early warning systems, but also indirectly through improved development of seismic shake maps, for example, and engineering seismology to improve the design of building and other critical structures. We also make our data available to the U.S. Geological Survey’s ShakeAlert early warning system.

Other disciplines are also starting to benefit from our research into optimal combination of GPS with low-cost MEMS sensors. The Geodetic Module built by us and deployed at GPS stations for this project, can also take as input meteorological sensors (pressure and temperature readings). The optimal combination of GPS and inexpensive meteorological sensors will make the practice of GPS meteorology more efficient and applicable at smaller and smaller scales, both temporally and spatially. This allows for improved tracking of extreme weather events such as atmospheric rivers, monsoons and their consequences such as forecasting flash flooding. The seismogeodetic combination of GPS and low-cost MEMS accelerometers will have considerable impact on structural monitoring and earthquake seismology, by providing estimates of the permanent displacements of a structure. This can be the basis of rapid tagging of large engineered structures such as hospitals, bridges, tall buildings, etc. after earthquakes but also provide long-term monitoring capabilities. Relatively inexpensive in situ observations of structures will provide a more direct way of assessing earthquake damage and in turn help refine seismic shake table maps.
